alert.note: Alert for Windham (Connecticut) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued July 16 at 4:04PM EDT until July 16 at 7:45PM EDT by NWS Boston
info.description: The National Weather Service in Norton has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... East Central Windham County in northern Connecticut... Southwestern Bristol County in southeastern Massachusetts... Bristol County in Rhode Island... Kent County in Rhode Island... Newport County in Rhode Island... Providence County in Rhode Island... Washington County in Rhode Island... * Until 745 PM EDT. * At 404 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 2.5 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 1 to 2 inches in 1 hour. While rainfall rates have started to level off from earlier excessive levels, additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are possible, as heavy rains and embedded thunderstorms over southeastern Connecticut will move into the warned area. Flash flooding is already occurring, and worsened or new areas of flooding are anticipated as more heavy rain moves into the warned area. HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms. SOURCE...Raadar, law enforcement and trained weather spotters. Law enforcement reports several roads in East Providence are flooded and impassable, including a portion of Pawtucket Ave near Allerton Ave. Oaklawn Ave in Cranston is also flooded and impassable per trained spotters. IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Providence, Fall River, Warwick, Cranston, Pawtucket, East Providence, Woonsocket, Coventry, Cumberland, North Providence, South Kingstown, West Warwick, Johnston, North Attleborough, North Kingstown, Newport, Bristol, Attleboro, Westerly and Smithfield. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Move to higher ground now. Act quickly to protect your life. Stay away or be swept away. River banks and culverts can become unstable and unsafe.
